Analysis

Test Protest
The student demonstration scheduled Thursday to
protest the janitors' work hours is clearly designed to
replicate the success achieved by the calendar change
demonstration on Commemoration Day two years ago.
Next week's rally raises two fundamental questions about
the nature of undergraduate participation in the University as an institution.
In some ways, it is doubtful how many people are
really interested in the plight of custodial workers. The
move to change the calendar affected every student
personally, while the personal problems experienced by
janitors who have to work nights cause nothing worse than
sympathy pains. Obviously, people who don't care about
the janitor situation have no business going to a rally
unless, like the mobs which continue to wreak turmoil in
the streets of Tehran, they enjoy causing trouble entirely
for its own sake.
But a more interesting problem is posed for students
who are in fact committed to the janitor cause. They must
decide whether a public demonstration is really an appropriate and effective means for redress. By refusing to
sanction the demonstration Wednesday night, the Student
Council has taken the position that such a rally, no matter
the justice of the cause it advances, would be politically inept.
While this view may be realistic given the status quo at
Johns Hopkins, students could assume a fundamentally
different role at this Uhiversity. Rather than customers
who pass through for the simple purpose of purchasing an
education, students actually form an integral part of the
academic institution. Without students, there would be no
University. However, students have very little institutional
control over the affairs of the University. The power
invested in the Student Council is nominal at best, so its
leaders know they must conserve its resources. But students who would like to see the janitors' hours changed
should be able to take some action toward that goal.
Only the non-institutional method of a demonstration
is available for them to use. So the rally Thursday is
appropriate. Whether it will be effective or not depends on
the number, of students who feel the issue is significant and
Worth doing something about.

Skinner: Good But Scorned
BY ASHTON TRICE

Occasionally, ironies of academic life are made apparent by
the random pairing in time of
two campus events. Next week
two such events will occur at
Hopkins which, one must
assume, are in no way mutually
dependent. These are yet
another step in the "resolution"
of the janitorial crisis, and the
Commemoration Day address
by Professor B.F. Skinner.
Skinner's earliest work was
ethological in character, dealing
with innate behavior in the ant
and eating in the rat, but this
quickly led him to the design of
his well-known "environmental
chamber," the Skinner box. His
box, unlike the boxes of his
intellectual forbearers, was programmed to dispense rewards for
work, rather than to motivate
work by inflicting aversive consequences for idleness. His rats
and pigeons have for years been
paid off for productivity under
relatively pleasant "working
conditions."
His first foray into designing human environments was his
infant air crib. The constraints

of cumbersome clothes, the
intrusion of noise during sleeping time, and the ambient
infection level of unfiltered air
were eliminated during times
when children would normally
be left in crib or play pen, and
parents were given anxiety-free
leisure time. In general, public
reaction was negative, although
the results have been highly

and too well-controlled.
Also too rational and controlled was the Utopian community described in his 1948
novel, Walden 1111. Walden II
maintained a high-level productivity based on efficient use of
work time, thereby augmenting
leisure time, and by positive
rather than aversive control
methods, including self-selection of work tasks and hours,
within the limitations based on

been demonstrated, with some

of control can increase the

As the authority controls those

is controlled by the behavior of
those under authority.
Skinner's attention turned
to a more formal analysis of

the publication of Science and

religion, economic structures

Fraternal Living
In the next several weeks, many young men who
happen to be Hopkins students will decide whether to join
a fraternity. Perhaps they will find it difficult - considering
that they are freshmen who can hardly be expected to
know enough to make a choice that will affect the next
three years of their lives.
Most people identify closely with their families from
the time they are small children until the time they finish
high school. When they get to Hopkins, they are assigned
to the dorms, which usually provide a definite community
at
However, in their second year, Hopkins students are
forced to fend for themselves in the outside world. Some
have friends with whom they can set up housekeeping;
Some do not. Most will end up experiencing some degree
of alienation.
Given this scenario, fraternity life offers a young
person a chance to continue as a member of a supportive
group. This can be valuable in cushioning a student from
the emotional shock of life on his own. In some cases,
though, it prevents people from maturing the way they
would if they were independent.
There are many different aspects to life in a fraternity.
Maturity and attitudes toward independence are perhaps
the most important criteria freshmen should use in making
their decisions about rush.

bass, drum set).

The student demonstration scheduled Thursday to

replicate the success achieved by the calendar change

the streets of Tehran, they enjoy causing trouble entirely
for its own sake.

decide whether a public demonstration is really an appropriate and effective means for redress. By refusing to

control over the affairs of the University. The power
invested in the Student Council is nominal at best, so its
leaders know they must conserve its resources. But students who would like to see the janitors' hours changed

is available for them to use. So the rally Thursday is
appropriate. Whether it will be effective or not depends on
the number, of students who feel the issue is significant and

Fraternal Living
In the next several weeks, many young men who
happen to be Hopkins students will decide whether to join
a fraternity. Perhaps they will find it difficult - considering
that they are freshmen who can hardly be expected to
know enough to make a choice that will affect the next
three years of their lives.
Most people identify closely with their families from
the time they are small children until the time they finish
high school. When they get to Hopkins, they are assigned
to the dorms, which usually provide a definite community
at
However, in their second year, Hopkins students are
forced to fend for themselves in the outside world. Some
have friends with whom they can set up housekeeping;
Some do not. Most will end up experiencing some degree
of alienation.
Given this scenario, fraternity life offers a young
person a chance to continue as a member of a supportive
group. This can be valuable in cushioning a student from
the emotional shock of life on his own. In some cases,
though, it prevents people from maturing the way they
would if they were independent.
There are many different aspects to life in a fraternity.
Maturity and attitudes toward independence are perhaps
the most important criteria freshmen should use in making
their decisions about rush.

Fencers Down 2,
Up Season Mark
BY MARCO A. PARILLO
Last Saturday, despite the
confusion generated by running
3 meets simultaneously in
Haverford's fieldhouse, it soon
became obvious that the Hopkins fencers would continue
their dominance over MAC opponents Haverford and UMBC,
as the Blue Jays beat Haverford
20-7 and UMBC 19-8, raising
their season record to a glittering
17-3 with 4 meets to go.
Hopkins used its best fencers against Haverford, and was
well rewarded as epeeman Adam
Stern, and sabremen Paul Cordts
and Nate Graham each went 3-0.
The foilmen, Erick Newman,
Evans Starzinger and Dave
Meyer each went 2-1, as did the
other two epeemen, Keith Pesto
and John Osby. The other
sabremen John Loonsk and
Mike Schwerin, were 1-0 and 0-2
respectively.
Against UMBC, Hopkins
regulars were sidelined as Coach
Oles decided to give the meet to
his subs to win or lose. The
response this time was overwhelming.
Sabremen
Mike
Schwerin, John Loonsk and Jim
Fowler went 1-2, 3-0 and 2-1
respectively. The epeemen didn't
fare quite so • well; John Osby

was 1-2 , Dave Nover 2-1 and
James Newman 2-1 but on the
foil team Dave Meyer and Kevin
Granville were undefeated and
Marco Parillo was 2-1. John
Loonsk won the deciding bout
against UMBC, while Keith Pesto
"Took the Bird" by winning the
clincher against Haverford.
Coach Oles, as he has often
been lately, was pleased with the
Blue Jay performance. "The
final scores were not really
indicative of the relative
strengths of the teams", the Jay
mentor noted. "There are 27
total bouts in each match, and
we won the Haverford meet at
14-6, while UMBC was beaten with our subs at 14-4. Our
policy is to win 14 bouts and
then substitute, so a close final
score is not necessarily a good
indication that the meet was a
close one."
This Saturday the Jay
swordsmen travel north again to
meet Rutgers (Newark) and
Seton Hall before returning
home for a final doubleheader
on the 24th. Coach Oles feels
that the SHU Pirates are the one
team left on the schedule that
could still beat the Jays, but
says, "The way things have
been going, don't look for an
upset."
